articles.headline: For Sale Now: U.S.-Supplied Weapons in Afghan Gun Shops
articles.snippet: The Taliban seized troves of American weapons and vehicles from surrendering Afghan soldiers. Now, gun dealers are doing a brisk business.
articles.abstract: The Taliban seized troves of American weapons and vehicles from surrendering Afghan soldiers. Now, gun dealers are doing a brisk business.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the chaos of the American military withdrawal and the Taliban takeover this summer, thousands of American-made weapons and tons of military equipment were seized by the militants as government military bases surrendered or were overrun.
articles.byline: By Ruhullah Khapalwak and David Zucchino

articles.headline: Facebook’s outage frustrates advertisers heading into the holiday season.
articles.snippet: “There may be heads on pikes by the end of this,” one agency executive said.
articles.abstract: “There may be heads on pikes by the end of this,” one agency executive said.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than five hours on Monday, while Facebook and Instagram were dark, David Herrmann fretted about ads.

articles.headline: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell Faces Reappointment Amid Tumult
articles.snippet: Mr. Powell is facing down progressive pushback and an ethics scandal as the White House considers his future.
articles.abstract: Mr. Powell is facing down progressive pushback and an ethics scandal as the White House considers his future.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Jerome H. Powell’s term as the chair of the Federal Reserve nears its expiration, President Biden’s decision over whether to keep him in the job has grown more complicated amid Senator Elizabeth Warren’s vocal opposition to his leadership and an ethics scandal that has engulfed his central bank.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Biden Scales Back His Agenda in Hopes of Bringing Moderates Onboard
articles.snippet: The president has conceded that his $3.5 trillion collection of spending programs and tax cuts will need to shrink substantially.
articles.abstract: The president has conceded that his $3.5 trillion collection of spending programs and tax cuts will need to shrink substantially.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Democratic leaders in Congress in recent days have slashed their ambitions for a major expansion of America’s social safety net to a package worth $2.3 trillion or less, which will force hard choices about how to scale back a proposal that the president hopes will be transformational.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: Facebook Whistle-Blower Urges Lawmakers to Regulate the Company
articles.snippet: Frances Haugen, who left the social network in May and leaked internal documents, gave senators rare insight into its inner workings.
articles.abstract: Frances Haugen, who left the social network in May and leaked internal documents, gave senators rare insight into its inner workings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former Facebook product manager who turned into a whistle-blower gave lawmakers an unvarnished look into the inner workings of the world’s largest social network on Tuesday and detailed how the company was deliberate in its efforts to keep people — including children — hooked to its service.

articles.headline: A Star Corporate Lawyer Now Set to Take On Corporate America
articles.snippet: How Jonathan Kanter, the Biden administration’s choice to be the Justice Department’s antitrust chief, became a progressive foe of Big Tech.
articles.abstract: How Jonathan Kanter, the Biden administration’s choice to be the Justice Department’s antitrust chief, became a progressive foe of Big Tech.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jonathan Kanter is an unlikely economic populist.
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Behind the Global Appeal of ‘Squid Game,’ a Country’s Economic Unease
articles.snippet: The dystopian Netflix hit taps South Korea’s worries about costly housing and scarce jobs, concerns familiar to its U.S. and international viewers.
articles.abstract: The dystopian Netflix hit taps South Korea’s worries about costly housing and scarce jobs, concerns familiar to its U.S. and international viewers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL — In “Squid Game,” the hit dystopian television show on Netflix, 456 people facing severe debt and financial despair play a series of deadly children’s games to win a $38 million cash prize in South Korea.

articles.headline: China Is Rocked by Uncertainty. Why Is Wall Street Bullish?
articles.snippet: Beijing is opening its financial system to foreign banks — and they have maintained their traditional openness to the Communist Party’s rule.
articles.abstract: Beijing is opening its financial system to foreign banks — and they have maintained their traditional openness to the Communist Party’s rule.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year has been unsettling for Chinese business. The ruling Communist Party has gone after the private sector industry by industry. The stock markets have taken a huge hit. The country’s biggest property developer is on the verge of collapse.

articles.headline: Why Democrats See 3 Governor’s Races as a Sea Wall for Fair Elections
articles.snippet: Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania all have Democratic governors and G.O.P.-led legislatures. And in all three battlegrounds, Republicans are pushing hard to rewrite election laws.
articles.abstract: Michigan, Wisconsin and Pennsylvania all have Democratic governors and G.O.P.-led legislatures. And in all three battlegrounds, Republicans are pushing hard to rewrite election laws.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADISON, Wis. — In three critical battleground states, Democratic governors have blocked efforts by Republican-controlled legislatures to restrict voting rights and undermine the 2020 election.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: It’s Time to Stop Paying for a VPN
articles.snippet: Many virtual private network services that were meant to protect your web browsing can no longer be trusted. Here are other ways.
articles.abstract: Many virtual private network services that were meant to protect your web browsing can no longer be trusted. Here are other ways.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’m done with paying for a virtual private network, a service that claims to protect your privacy when you’re connected to a public Wi-Fi network at the local coffee shop, the airport or a hotel.

articles.headline: Facebook Hearing Strengthens Calls for Regulation in Europe
articles.snippet: A whistle-blower who told Congress about the tech giant’s inner workings has spoken with top policymakers in Brussels, Britain and France about the need for tougher oversight.
articles.abstract: A whistle-blower who told Congress about the tech giant’s inner workings has spoken with top policymakers in Brussels, Britain and France about the need for tougher oversight.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The congressional testimony from the Facebook whistle-blower, Frances Haugen, has intensified calls in Europe for new regulations aimed at the social media company and other Silicon Valley giants, proposals considered by many to be among the most stringent and far-reaching in the world.

articles.headline: What the Debt Ceiling Means for Social Security and More
articles.snippet: The Treasury secretary says the government will run out of money to spend if Congress doesn’t raise the debt ceiling. Here’s what that could mean for programs that help millions of Americans.
articles.abstract: The Treasury secretary says the government will run out of money to spend if Congress doesn’t raise the debt ceiling. Here’s what that could mean for programs that help millions of Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal government is about two weeks away from being unable to pay its bills — and that could delay benefit payments to tens of millions of retirees, Medicare and Medicaid providers, and numerous others receiving checks from the U.S. Treasury.
